headline.main: Today in Small Business: Saving the Family Business

docs.abstract: A small company offers cheaper web hosting than Amazon. South Carolina small businesses prepare for rising sea levels. And Pizza Hut invades Iraq.
docs.snippet: A small company offers cheaper web hosting than Amazon. South Carolina small businesses prepare for rising sea levels. And Pizza Hut invades Iraq.

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 7.5 million people are expected to sign up for private health coverage this year under President Barack Obama's healthcare law, the top U.S. health official said on Thursday.

headline.main: Obamacare Enrollment to Surpass 7.5 Million: U.S. Official
headline.print_headline: Obamacare Enrollment to Surpass 7.5 Million: U.S. Official

docs.snippet: More than 7.5 million people are expected to sign up for private health coverage this year under President Barack Obama's healthcare law, the top U.S. health official said on Thursday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Enrollment for the president's health care law has grown to 7.5 million Americans, the Obama administration announced Thursday, handing President Barack Obama and the Democrats bigger coverage numbers to tout in the face of election-year attacks.
docs.snippet: Enrollment for the president's health care law has grown to 7.5 million Americans, the Obama administration announced Thursday, handing President Barack Obama and the Democrats bigger coverage numbers to tout in the face of election-year attacks.

docs.lead_paragraph: Rite Aid has left the recovery ward and appears ready to break into a sprint after booking its sixth straight quarterly profit and making a deal to strengthen the drugstore chain's foothold in the burgeoning health clinic market.

headline.main: Another Profitable Quarter, Rite Aid Breaks Out
headline.print_headline: Another Profitable Quarter, Rite Aid Breaks Out

docs.snippet: Rite Aid has left the recovery ward and appears ready to break into a sprint after booking its sixth straight quarterly profit and making a deal to strengthen the drugstore chain's foothold in the burgeoning health clinic market.

headline.main: It's Official: No Deductible Caps in Small-Business Health Plans

docs.abstract: The legislative fix may allow small-business owners to shift some of their health care costs to their workers.
docs.snippet: The legislative fix may allow small-business owners to shift some of their health care costs to their workers.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: House Republicans rallied behind a slashing budget blueprint on Thursday, passing a non-binding but politically imposing measure that promises a balanced federal ledger in 10 years with sweeping budget cuts and termination of health care coverage under the Affordable Care Act.

headline.main: House Passes Ryan Budget With Big Cuts
headline.print_headline: House Passes Ryan Budget With Big Cuts

docs.snippet: House Republicans rallied behind a slashing budget blueprint on Thursday, passing a non-binding but politically imposing measure that promises a balanced federal ledger in 10 years with sweeping budget cuts and termination of health care coverage...

docs.lead_paragraph: Announcing his campaign to return to Washington by way of New Hampshire, former Massachusetts Sen. Scott Brown tweaked the state's "Live Free or Die" motto Thursday to bash both President Barack Obama's health care overhaul law and Democrat Jeanne Shaheen's support for it.

headline.main: Senate Hopeful Brown: Health Law Erodes Freedom
headline.print_headline: Senate Hopeful Brown: Health Law Erodes Freedom

docs.lead_paragraph: Many doctors said they favored the sharing of Medicare payment data but worried that it left out important details.
docs.abstract: Release of Medicare payment data is getting mixed reviews from doctors, who say they favor sharing information but worry that data presented omits important details and may paint an unfairly negative picture of individual doctors.
docs.snippet: Many doctors said they favored the sharing of Medicare payment data but worried that it left out important details.

byline.original: By DENISE GRADY and SHERI FINK

docs.lead_paragraph: Ophthalmologists say treatments like cataract operations and an expensive macular degeneration drug skew their Medicare reimbursements.

headline.main: Eye Doctors Say Their Profits Are Smaller Than Data Makes Them Look
headline.print_headline: Eye Doctors Say Their Profits Are Smaller Than They Look

docs.abstract: Newly released data reveals that ophthalmologists were the biggest recipients of Medicare money in 2012; reasons say volumes about an aging population and specialty that does many procedures, all well-reimbursed by Medicare; findings also reveal the difficulty of interpreting the Medicare data; ophthalmologists say their high representation among the list of big recipients is misleading, since bulk of Medicare money goes to costs of drugs they administer.
docs.snippet: Ophthalmologists say treatments like cataract operations and an expensive macular degeneration drug skew their Medicare reimbursements.

byline.original: By ANDREW POLLACK and REED ABELSON

docs.lead_paragraph: Some of the cars being recalled by General Motors for problems related to the ignition switch that are still being driven by their owners may still pose a danger to the owner and other motorists.

headline.main: Debate Over Risk of Driving G.M.’s Recalled Cars
headline.print_headline: Debate Over Risk of Driving G.M.’s Recalled Cars

docs.abstract: Rising debate over whether General Motors cars with faulty ignition switches pose a continuing danger reflects growing impatience with company's timetable for repairs, and fact that most of the unrepaired cars remain on the road; GM has maintained, in the nearly two months since it announced it was recalling Cobalts and other small cars, that the vehicles are safe to drive under certain conditions.
docs.snippet: Some of the cars being recalled by General Motors for problems related to the ignition switch that are still being driven by their owners may still pose a danger to the owner and other motorists.

byline.contributor: Bill Vlasic, Rebecca R. Ruiz, Danielle Ivory and Alain Delaquérière contributed reporting.
byline.original: By HILARY STOUT and RACHEL ABRAMS
